data.question: What is the absolute configuration of ether (-)-2 based on capillary GC analysis?
What percentage of inversion of configuration does acid 1 undergo to produce ether 2?
What is the result of the stereospecific C-C bond cleavage in acyclic systems as demonstrated by acid 1?
data.answer: Producing ether 2 with 99.5% inversion of configuration

data.question: What is the significance of the reaction that produces ether 2 from acid 1 in terms of configurational retention versus inversion?
data.answer: It is the most stereospecific C-C bond cleavage ever seen in an acyclic system

data.question: What role do the highly electronegative substituents of acid 1 play in the reaction to produce ether 2?
data.answer: They may cause the quenching proton of triethylene glycol to be in the required position opposite the carboxyl leaving group

data.question: What does the synthesis of optically active anesthetics involve?
data.answer: Use of the reaction that produces ether 2 from acid 1

data.question: What is the relationship between the absolute configuration of (-)-6 and the configuration of ether (-)-2?
data.answer: Since (-)-6 is known to have an (S) configuration, ether (-)-2 also has an (S) configuration

data.question: Why is the reaction that produces ether 2 from acid 1 considered surprising?
data.answer: Because it results in a high level of inversion of configuration, contrary to most acyclic systems which exhibit retention of configuration

data.question: How does the reaction that produces ether 2 from acid 1 compare to decarboxylation processes in terms of configurational retention?
data.answer: It shows nearly complete inversion of configuration, unlike carboxylic acids which are known to produce products with a medium to high degree of configurational retention or racemization

data.question: What future plans are mentioned for the reaction that produces ether 2 from acid 1?
data.answer: Future reports will describe use of this reaction in the synthesis of optically active anesthetics and new mechanistic data

data.question: Is the reaction that produces ether 2 from acid 1 less selective in solvents other than the one used?
data.answer: Yes, the reaction is less selective in other solvents

data.question: Does the reaction that produces ether 2 from acid 1 exhibit a lower level of inversion of configuration compared to other systems?
data.answer: False, it exhibits a very high level of inversion of configuration

data.question: Is the absolute configuration of ether (-)-2 determined to be (R) based on capillary GC analysis?
data.answer: False, it is determined to be (S)

data.question: Is the reaction that produces ether 2 from acid 1 considered the least stereospecific C-C bond cleavage seen in an acyclic system?
data.answer: False, it is considered the most stereospecific

data.question: Are the highly electronegative substituents of acid 1 irrelevant to the reaction's selectivity?
data.answer: False, they play a crucial role in the reaction's high level of inversion of configuration

data.question: Is the synthesis of optically active anesthetics unrelated to the reaction that produces ether 2 from acid 1?
data.answer: False, the synthesis of optically active anesthetics will use this reaction

data.question: Does the reaction that produces ether 2 from acid 1 always exhibit retention of configuration?
data.answer: False, it exhibits inversion of configuration
